title: AB 2514
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 34171 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to define terms related to administrative budget and administrative cost allowance for successor agencies. The administrative budget for successor agencies is defined as the budget for administrative costs, with an administrative cost allowance set at 5% of property tax allocated to the successor agency for the period January 1, 2012, through June 30, 2012. This allowance may be up to 3% for fiscal years ending on June 30, 2016, but not less than $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the successor agency. Starting July 1, 2016, the administrative cost allowance for successor agencies is up to 3% of the property tax distributed by the county auditor-controller in the previous fiscal year. The allowance cannot be less than $250,000 unless reduced by the oversight board or by agreement with the department. Starting July 1, 2016, a successor agency's annual administrative costs cannot exceed 50% of the total Redevelopment Property Tax Trust Fund distributed to pay enforceable obligations in the previous fiscal year. This limit applies regardless of whether the costs are paid within the administrative cost allowance or not, but excludes costs paid from bond proceeds or grant funds. The administrative cost allowance is the sole funding source for legal expenses related to civil actions. Employee costs for project implementation activities are not considered administrative costs. "Designated local authority" refers to a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes certain defined criteria. The "designated local authority" is a public entity formed under specific sections. An "enforceable obligation" includes bonds issued with required debt service and reserve set-asides. Loans borrowed by the redevelopment agency for lawful purposes and payments required by the federal government or state law, including federal base reuse obligations for the former Norton Air Force Base, must be repaid according to mandatory terms. The county auditor-controller makes passthrough payments and legally enforceable payments for agencies' employees, including pension payments and obligations from collective bargaining agreements. Layoff or termination costs for city employees who worked for the former redevelopment agency are considered enforceable obligations payable from property tax funds. Employee obligations remain payable if transferred to the entity assuming housing functions. The county auditor-controller makes payments for agencies' employees, including pension payments and collective bargaining obligations. Layoff or termination costs for city employees who worked for the former redevelopment agency are enforceable obligations payable from property tax funds. Employee obligations remain enforceable if transferred to the entity assuming housing functions. The oversight board has the authority to appeal judgments or settlements against the former redevelopment agency. They can also terminate agreements or contracts with approval and provide compensation for such terminations. Titles or headings on documents do not determine enforceable obligations. Contracts or agreements necessary for the administration or operation of the successor agency, including litigation expenses, settlements, office space, equipment, supplies, and insurance costs, shall be paid out of the administrative cost allowance starting January 1, 2016. A sponsoring entity may provide funds to a successor agency for legal expenses related to civil actions. If the successor agency wins the case, the funds are repayable. If the successor agency loses, the funds are considered a grant and not repayable. Repayments owed to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Fund of a redevelopment agency must be approved by the oversight board and transferred to the Low and Moderate Income Housing Asset Fund for affordable housing purposes. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an "enforceable obligation" in relation to agreements between the city and former redevelopment agency. Written agreements for indebtedness obligations issued before December 31, 2010, or for refunding existing obligations before June 27, 2011, may be considered enforceable obligations. The curr_chunk clarifies that agreements between the city and former redevelopment agency can be deemed enforceable obligations if they pertain to certain criteria, such as indebtedness obligations issued before December 31, 2010, or for refunding existing obligations before June 27, 2011. The curr_chunk specifies that agreements between the city, county, or city and county and the former redevelopment agency can be considered enforceable obligations if they involve repayment of loans or development obligations from federal agencies. Contracts or agreements between the former redevelopment agency and other public agencies outside of redevelopment project areas that were not properly authorized under Part 1 shall be void, except for housing-related contracts authorized under Part 1. The curr_chunk defines "Indebtedness obligations" as bonds or other debt issued by the redevelopment agency, "Oversight board" as entities established by Section 34179, and "Recognized obligation" as listed in the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule. The curr_chunk further defines "Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule" as the document outlining minimum payment amounts for enforceable obligations until June 30, 2016, and "School entity" as defined in the Revenue and Taxation Code. Additionally, it clarifies "Successor agency" as the entity succeeding the former redevelopment agency. The curr_chunk defines key terms such as "taxing entities" as cities, counties, special districts, and school entities receiving property tax passthrough payments. It also clarifies "property taxes" as all tax revenues, and "sponsoring entity" as the entity authorizing redevelopment agency creation. The curr_chunk defines key terms such as "Department" as the Department of Finance, "sponsoring entity" as the entity authorizing redevelopment agency creation, and "final judicial determination" as a court decision not further appealed. It also specifies the "housing entity administrative cost allowance" from July 1, 2014, to July 1, 2018, as up to 1% of property tax allocated to the Redevelopment Obligation Retirement Fund. The housing entity administrative cost allowance is remitted by the successor agency to the local housing authority that assumed the housing functions of the former redevelopment agency on January 2 and July 1, as listed on the Recognized Obligation Payment Schedule. If there are insufficient funds in the Redevelopment Obligations Retirement Fund, the unpaid amount can be carried over to future Recognized Obligation Payment Schedules without a five-year limit.
